dialogues.MANDELA:
[1]Morning boys. How are you?

[10]-- please assemble the staff for me. Whoever has not already left.

[17]I couldn't help noticing the empty offices as I came to work today. And all the packing boxes. 13. 
[18]Now, of course, if you want to leave, that is your right. And if you feel in your heart that you cannot work with your new government, then it is better that you do leave, right away. 
[19]But if you are packing up because you fear that your language, or the color of your skin, or who you served previously, disqualifies you from working here now, I am here to tell you, have no such fear. Wat is verby is verby. What's past is past. We look to the future, now. 
[20]We need your help. We want your help. If you would like to stay, you will be doing your country a great service. 
[21]I ask only that you do your jobs to the best of your abilities, and with good hearts. I promise to do the same. If we can manage that, our country will be a shining light in the world. 
[22]You look agitated, Jason.

[55]Brothers, sisters, comrades, I am here because I feel strongly that you made a decision today without sufficient information or foresight. 41. 
[56]I am aware of your earlier vote. I am aware that it was unanimous. Nonetheless, I propose that we restore the Springboks. Restore their name, their emblem and their colors, immediately. 
[57]Let me tell you why ... 
[58]... on Robben Island, in Pollsmoor Prison, my jailers were all Afrikaners. For twenty seven years, I studied them. I learned their language, I read their history, I read their poetry. I had to know my enemy, in order to prevail against him. And we prevailed, did we not? All of us here ... we prevailed. 
[59]Our enemy is no longer the Afrikaner. They are our fellow South Africans, our partners in democracy. 
[60]And they treasure Springbok rugby. If we take that away, we lose them. We prove that we are what they feared we would be. We have to be better than that. 42. 
[61]We have to surprise them with compassion, with restraint, and generosity. 
[62]Yes, I know. All the things they denied us. 
[63]But this is not the time to enjoy a moment's petty revenge. This is the time to build our nation using every single brick available to us - - even if that brick comes clothed in green and gold. 
[64]You elected me. You elected me to be your leader. Let me lead you now. Who is with me on this? 
[65]Who is with me? 
[66]A luxury. All we needed was one more yes than no. 
[67]Well, as you know, I am an obedient party member. 
[68]But, I must. This minority still controls the army, the police, and the economy. Without them, we cannot address the other problems. 44. 
[69]It's a human calculation. If we take away what they cherish -- the Springboks, their national anthem -- we just reinforce the cycle of fear between us. 
[70]I will do what I must to break this cycle. Or it will destroy us.

[153]What man would not be pleased to be dancing with a beautiful woman like you? 
[154]Indeed not. My father was a Xhosa chief, and therefore a polygamist. As you know, I am not. But when I look at you ... I envy my father. 
[155]Out of the night that covers me, Black as the pit from pole to pole, I thank whatever gods may be For my unconquerable soul. 
[156]In the fell clutch of circumstance I have not winced nor cried aloud. Under the bludgeonings of chance My head is bloody, but unbow'd. 105. 
[157]Beyond this place of wrath and tears Looms but the Horror of the shade, And yet the menace of the years Finds and shall find me unafraid. 
[158]It matters not how strait the gate, How charged with punishment the scroll, I am the master of my fate: I am the captain of my soul.

[19]Well, you know what they say about soccer -- it's gentleman's game played by hooligans. One the other hand, rugby is a hooligan's game played by -- 
[20]Thanks for reminding me. 
[21]Give it a spin when you pass it. Like this. 
[22]Come on, man. There's nothing more you can do today. 
[23]Once or twice, yes. 
[24]We all do. 
[25]Did they get clearance for this?
dialogues.BOLAND BOTHA:
[1]Francois Pienaar's team came to Loftus Versfeld stadium this afternoon, unprepared and arrogant. 31. 
[2]They left 80 minutes later with their tails between their legs, like whipped mongrels. And I, for one, am glad. Not because we lost, but because there's now no way to disguise the fact that we are completely and utterly unprepared to reenter the world of top-notch international rugby. 
[3]The Rugby World Cup is now less than a year away, and I, for one, am relieved that we are the host nation, and therefore qualify automatically for the tournament. Because I'm not sure we would get in on merit alone. 
[4]Pienaar's team played without discipline, without strategy and without courage. 
[5]They brought shame upon our nation, and I, for one, can say without fear of contradiction, that today, these fifteen so-called men did not deserve to wear the hallowed green and gold. 
[6]This is Boland Botha coming to you live from Cape Town airport -- 
[7]-- where the Springbok flight has just landed. 
[8]The green and gold have one week to put the finishing touches to their gruelling training program -- 
[9]-- and I, for one, have to admit to being cautiously excited. 82. 
[10]I say cautiously, because in my humble opinion -- 
[11]-- this team has been over-trained on the field, and over-committed off it. 
[12]Which makes beating a powerhouse Australian side in the Cup opener next week a tall order, especially since this is an inexperienced team with a history of coming up short in big matches. This is Boland 
[13]Tell us, Mr. President, have you always been a rugby fan? 
[14]How do you think the Springboks will do? 
[15]Now, it's been said that you used to support any team who played against the Springboks. 
[16]We're at Ellis Park on this historic day, where, even this early, crowd excitement is at fever 
[17]-- because their beloved green and gold have somehow managed to exceed all expectations. 
[18]But now they come up against a team that is unlike any other they have played. 
[19]These All Blacks are possibly one of the greatest international sides ever, with a player in Jonah Lomu who is as dominant as any this correspondent has ever seen. 
[20]To lose to them is no disgrace. To lose to them in the finals is, in fact, an honor. 
[21]I say this with absolutely no negativity. I simply want to save people from the heartbreak of unrealistic expectations. 
[22]So, take a reality check, sit back and share an afternoon with one billion fellow fans around the world. And as you do, feel a special pride in having made it this far. This is Boland Botha, signing off and sitting back at Ellis Park. 
[23]Francois ... a few words ... 
[24]... great game, but I don't think you could've done it without the amazing support of these 63,000 South Africans --
dialogues.MINISTER OF SPORT:
[1]Sorry I'm late. 
[2]How's it going? 
[3]Maybe it's just as well. 
[4]
[5]This could be the last time we have to look at the green and gold. 
[6]The World Cup is played every four years. Sixteen teams qualify from around the world. 
[7]Four pools of four teams each, playing in nine different venues around the country. Two teams will advance from each pool to the quarter finals. 
[8]Australia won the previous World Cup. New Zealand won the one before that. 69. 
[9]They're both clear favorites to reach the finals this time. According to the experts, we'll reach the quarter finals, and no further. 
[10]You make a personal appearance at the finals, and at the opening match between the Springboks and Australia. The finals will be broadcast to over a billion people around the world, live. 
[11]Everyone thinks they'll beat us. And if they do, we'll have to go through England and the All Blacks just to get to the Final. 
[12]The All Blacks beat Ireland 43 to 
[13]-- they beat Wales 34 to 9, they beat Japan 145 to 17. 
[14]It's a new international record.  They beat Scotland 48 to 30 in the quarter finals. You saw the match with England. 
[15]If opposing teams play them straight up, Jonah Lomu runs wild. If they focus on Lomu, that leaves others free. And, also, there's the business of the haka. 116. 
[16]My sources tell me that half of the All Black matches are won before the first whistle, because of it. 
[17]I have the coach's number. You could call him and ask. 
[18]Maybe we won't. They're favored two-to-one. Madiba, we've already exceeded all expectations. On and off the field. 
[19]Seven minutes.
dialogues.NERINE:
[1]He's just bitter because the Springboks were boycotted when he played. 
[2]He knows I'd bloody kill him. 
[3]What? Who was it? 
[4]Who with? 
[5]Francois, relax. You've met him before. 
[6]You didn't even vote for him. 55. 
[7]You won't. I'll pick you up right here. 
[8]So ...? 
[9]What's he like? 
[10]Well? What did he want? 
[11]Ag, come on Francois. It's like talking to a bloody brick wall. What did he want? 
[12]You know the best thing about you being the captain? 
[13]You don't have to share a room. 95. 
[14]Francois, come on. It's been weeks. 
[15]What's this? 
[16]How does a poem help you play rugby? 
[17]Imagine being able to see Cape Town so close by. 
[18]I brought one of your mom's protein shakes. 
[19]Thinking about tomorrow? 119.
dialogues.COACH:
[1]It's that terrorist, Mandela. They let him out. Remember this day, boys. It's the day our country went to the dogs. 
[2]Again! 
[3]I haven't even begun. We may not be the most talented team in the world -- but we're going to be the fittest. 
[4]And back! 
[5]One week, boys. 
[6]Enough fun and games! We've still got work to do. 
[7]There's nothing more we can do. The game plan's good. It's just a matter of the boys executing it tomorrow. 
[8]I hope you're not that slow next week. 
[9]That's not good enough. 
[10]Let's hope the Samoans don't injure it again. 
[11]Forty minute postponement. They're trying to clear the field. 
[12]How's the feeling in the dressing room? 
[13]Nobody gives us a bloody chance. I like that. It plays into their one weakness. 
[14]Their vanity. They're already counting the win. But they want to win with style, the way they won all their other matches. They want to show the world how beautiful All Black rugby is. I just want to show the bloody world how hard we tackle.
dialogues.TV ANNOUNCER:
[1]Today marks the beginning of a new era in South Africa -- 
[2]-- as President Mandela takes office in Pretoria, facing issues that range from economic stagnation and unemployment to rising crime -- 8. 
[3]-- while at the same time balancing black aspirations -- 
[4]-- with white fears. 
[5]... and in London, President Mandela made quite an impression on the Queen -- 
[6]-- as he concluded a gruelling trip 
[7]Today, President Mandela announced that, in his opinion -- 
[8]-- his salary is too high. 
[9]He has therefore decided to donate a third of his monthly income to charity. 
[10]President Mandela said that he wished to set an example to other leaders and cabinet ministers. 53. 
[11]We're looking at the remains of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, America, which was destroyed today in a massive explosion. 
[12]No one has claimed responsibility yet, but authorities say that the timing and target mark this as the work of white, right-wing fanatics. An act of revenge for the FBI killings in Waco, Texas. 
[13]The explosive, a truck bomb, was apparently a simple mixture of commonly available industrial and agricultural materials. 
[14]So far, the official death toll stands at over a 100 people, which includes at least 12 children from a day care center in the Federal building.
dialogues.MARY:
[1]Here's your muti. I warmed the milk tonight. 
[2]Your daughter called, to cancel her visit this weekend. 33. 
[3]No, she didn't.  She said to tell you she was sorry. 
[4]Do you need anything else tonight? 
[5]Good night, Madiba. Sleep well. 
[6]Mr. Pienaar? 
[7]This way, please. 
[8]Go on in. 
[9]It's time for bed. 
[10]You need to sleep. The doctor said. 
[11]You know him. He won't do that. 
[12]I'll cancel everything. 
[13]The All Blacks play England tomorrow. Then, we'll know. 
[14]Yes, Madiba.
dialogues.SPRINGBOK HOOKER:

dialogues.NSC FIREBRAND:
[1]... and now for the next item on our agenda. 
[2]The NSC executive proposes a full membership vote on the following motion ... 
[3]... that as a prominent symbol of the apartheid era, the colors, emblem and name of the Springboks be eliminated immediately ... 
[4]... and that all sports teams representing South Africa shall be known forthwith as the Proteas. 
[5]We will submit this motion to a hand vote. 36. 
[6]In the event of a close count, we will go to a written ballot. (the moment he's been

[10]Brothers, sisters, members of the choir -- we would only interrupt such beautiful music for something truly important. In this case, for someone truly important.  Please welcome President Mandela!
dialogues.RUGBY PRESIDENT:
